archive/history-of-asia/5-year-plans.htm.title: 5-Year Plans
archive/history-of-asia/5-year-plans.htm.description:
Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-24
The 5-year plans were plans that were attempts by the CCP to Industrialization, of which the 1st one was especially successful, reaching most of its quotas and helping to set China's economy and industry on the right track - steel and iron production tripled , coal doubled in production, and railway mileage increased from 15k miles to 18k miles. However, the 2nd 5-year plan (a.k.a the Great Leap Forward) failed - goals were set too high Overall: (B-)
What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (A+ w/ Great Leap Forward) The 5-Year plans demonstrate how political leaders can create great reforms for their country, increasing the economic output
Great Leap Forward shows negative side Either way, we can see that political leaders have a large impact on the economy How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (F) Very difficult to argue, as the 5 year plans were centrally planned and coordinated. What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (S) The 5-year plans led to both economic success and failure
The first 5-year plans were extremely successful, and were how China even started Industrialization - without the 1st 5-year plan, China would not be able to become an export nation and succeed
But the 2nd 5-year plan highlights the weakness of Nationalization when the government tries to control to much, showing how it leads to economic failure.

archive/history-of-asia/228.html.description:
Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-25
An anti-government uprising that was triggered by the police shooting a civlian and led to protests, which were suppressed with a brutal crackdown and started Martial Law in Taiwan, and was the start of the White Terror period. Overall: (B-) What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (A+) 228 shows us how political leaders can prevent reform, and can prevent changes in a country Governments/leaders can have violent crackdowns and suppression How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (A+) This event can show us how the people are overruled by political leaders, preventing the people from contributing to change It can also show us how people's movements trigger that cause political change, whether it's crackdowns or reforms What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (F) No relation.

archive/history-of-asia/anti-rightist-mo.title: Anti-Rightist Movement
archive/history-of-asia/anti-rightist-mo.description:
Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-10
The campaign that Mao immediately started right after he got too much criticism after the Hundred Flowers Campaign, the persecution of everyone who criticized the government. Afterwards, if you were labeled a rightist (which stems from people who are conservative, opposite of communism) you were opposing progress. This led to the loss of intellectuals from China. This was led by Deng Xiaoping, who actually ended up going against this when he started his Deng's Economic Reforms.
Overall: (B+) Has to be combined with Hundred Flowers to be really powerful but it's better to use this individually than Hundred Flowers if you want to use it individually What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (A+) This shows how political leaders control the flow of information Mao was able to immediately restrict or relax information flow Able to show how political leaders can contribute to a lack of change How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (A) This is actually really good as a counter, to show how political leaders wield so much power and control information that people can't contribute to political changes Better to use this than Hundred Flowers, as it shows how people can't criticize the government What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (B-) Led to economic failure later on as China ran out of intellectual

archive/history-of-asia/communes-and-col.title: Communes and Collectives
archive/history-of-asia/communes-and-col.description:
Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-23
Communes and Collectives were motivated by the government in order to try and increase production. Similar to State Owned Enterprises, collectives suffered from inefficiency as people weren't economically motivated due to Nationalization of agriculture. However, collectives, small systems with only ~50 farmers where the excess could be sold were highly successful. Communes suffered from the Great Leap Forward and many died from famine. Overall: (A-) What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (A) Political leaders can forcibly create new social structures Communes show how political leaders have immense power to create and organize social structures. How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (B) People can work together in order to drive changes - communes allowed people to increase their status and help further their own goals Communes show how people can decide how to manage their own structures within their own villages, and even groups of villages What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (A) Collectives show us how economic success in China was driven by motivation for people to produce more - if people got benefits, productivity of the economy increased Contrasted with communes which show us how top-down command structures in China led to economic failure

archive/history-of-asia/cult-of-personal.title: Cult of Personality
archive/history-of-asia/cult-of-personal.description: Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-27A cult of personality is when a leader or other central figure has a cult-like following formed around them, especially in authoritarian regimes - Mao is a good example, where during his lifetime he gained a cult following Overall: What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? How did people contribute to political changes in their country? What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan?

archive/history-of-asia/cultural-revolut.title: Cultural Revolution
archive/history-of-asia/cultural-revolut.description:
Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-23Two in one because it's so important!
The Cultural Revolution was the reclamation of power of Mao Zedong from reformers like Deng Xiaoping. Mao spoke about the Four Olds and created the Red Guards to remove all western influences, which significantly hurt and drove away intellectuals. He closed down higher education to support the Red Guards and gather more support in 1966. Overall: (A) What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (S) Mao Zedong initiated the Cultural Revolution, and his leadership and ideological vision were central to the movement's goals and intensity. This shows us how political leaders lead huge movements and create big political changes, whether within a party (regained power) or within a nation (basically removed all intellectuals) How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (A)
The widespread participation of the Red Guards and student population amplified the revolution's impact and led to significant social upheaval. This shows us how people, even if motivated by political leaders, can still have power and upheave social structures and harm certain groups (intellectuals) What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (B-)
The Cultural Revolution led to economic disruption due to the focus on ideological purity over practical economic management. Factories and schools were shut down, and skilled workers and intellectuals were persecuted, slowing down Industrialization
Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-23
The Four Olds were old habits, old ideas, old customs, and old culture, which Mao tried to remove in the Cultural Revolution. These encompassed traditional ways of thinking, behaving, and living that were deeply ingrained in Chinese society for centuries. For example, old habits might include traditional family structures and ancestor worship. The aim was to eradicate these elements and replace them with new, socialist ones - to get rid of western influences. Overall: B- What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (A) The four olds show us how how political leaders can alter the course of their country The removal of western influences helps to show how political leaders can reshape a country's identity and values How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (B+)
The Red Guards followed the idea of removing the Four Olds, and thus contributed to fundamentally altering the values of China While it was led by political leaders, they show how the people are how changes actually get implemented in real life. What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (C+) The removal of western influences and intellectuals slowed down economic growth and made it much more difficult for China to grow in the future A stretch...

archive/history-of-asia/deng's-economic-.title: Deng's Economic Reforms
archive/history-of-asia/deng's-economic-.description:
Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-25
Deng, after the cultural revolution and Hua Guofeng reclaimed power and immediately tried to reform China, seeing how Mao's policies had failed. This made him pivot China to "socialist with Chinese characteristics" with a lot of market-based ideologies and going against Mao's principles: he linked economic rewards to productivity via Special Economic Zones, Household Responsibility System and Town and Village Enterprises, reduced the importance of State Owned Enterprises, and conversion of China to an export economy.SEZ: 30% growth/year Guangdong, majority of SEZs contributed to 40% growth/year and 20% of all chinese exports TVEs: 7% per capita income growth/year Household Responsibility System led to 10% agri growth/year Overall: (B+/A- but please break this up into individual reforms) What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (A+) Political leaders can introduce reforms that can dramatically shift the political and economic direction of a nation With "socialism with Chinese Characteristics", Deng shifted the entire country to a more Western/Capitalist nation. How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (B) Use the specific evidence, it's a lot better... People were able to contribute directly to changes in their country, and bring China to become a superpower What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (S but you can and should talk about each reform individually) The widespread reforms were an essential part to China's own "economic miracle", as the shift to capitalism

archive/history-of-asia/derecognization-.title: Derecognization of ROC
archive/history-of-asia/derecognization-.description: Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-06In 1971 China was admitted to the United Nations replacing the Republic of China (Taiwan), labeled "the greatest defeat of the U.S in the history of the United Nations". Afterwards, the U.S stopped supporting the R.O.C and instead decided on it's One China Policy which tried to keep the idea of a "single China" but they stopped trying to upset the status quo. Overall: (C- tier) Too much of a stretch for a lot of these What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (B) The U.S was able to give Taiwan a lot of political capital and continue to have it recognized for a long time Afterwards, it stopped Taiwan from reentering via the One China Policy It also shows us how political leaders can play a role of Identity inside a country - Taiwan's derecognition was a reason why How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (F) N/A, no direct connection to people What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (C) Could argue that global acceptance of China allowed China to start becoming a world superpower, and showed how economic success allowed China to participate on the world stage might be too much of a stretch Benefited China's trade, global acceptance led to economic success

archive/history-of-asia/gambling-in-hist.description: Tags: #untagged Date: 2025-05-28One-Child Policy & Political vs. People political change Passed

archive/history-of-asia/great-leap-forwa.title: Great Leap Forward
archive/history-of-asia/great-leap-forwa.description:
[Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-24
The Great Leap Forward was the second 5-Year Plans where Mao attempted to rapidly increase Industrialization, for example, by having everyone participate in iron manufacturing. However, these goals were unrealistic and led to widespread economic failure. Communes and Collectives suffered as government officials inflated production numbers, causing immense food taxes leading to widespread starvation. Overall: (B-) What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (A-) This shows us how political leaders can fail and cause immense suffering While political leaders can attempt reforms, due to their immense power they can also cause great destruction How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (F) No relation. What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (A+)
Overinflated numbers and overinflated goals led to economic failure in China, and it was especially clear in the case of Communes and Collectives, where Nationalization of farms led to poor management The government officials in charge did not understand what was needed.

archive/history-of-asia/history.html.title: History
archive/history-of-asia/history.html.description:
#historyInfo Italicized is counter Bolded is good evidence, solid and great for support Highlighted is extremely good evidence for this EQ, the central core piece you should think about Tiers for EQ: F, you literally cannot even argue this, don't even try to use this as evidence D, very very niche, an enormous stretch if you want to use this as evidence C, a stretch but can support a specific key point B, mediocre, you could use this in your essay if you needed a filler piece or supporting piece but never your main piece A, really good evidence, able to be used in a lot of ways S, one of the essential pieces of evidence you need, without this, you can't talk about the EQ fully Essay writing theory Skip this if you only need evidence! This is just some theory for writing the essay. First off, looking at constraints - we need evidence from China and Taiwan for each EQ, a counter, and CATS themes As such, I have grouped and identified EQ, Counter, and a general "umbrella term" that you could argue. There are many ways to talk about the CATS themes, but mainly I wanted to show the strongest evidence for each selection. To get the most out of this, only use this to find evidence and look for new evidence you haven't considered yet. Then I would recommend planning out some practice essays, thinking of how you want to argue these, then memorize dates. One of the other things you should do is look at the CATS themes to find which "bucket" or "group" each evidence is in - this helps you build more connections and have a more coherent argument. E->A->R Always show the evidence, analyze it, which means that you explain why it shows some aspect of the theme/thesis, then relate it back to the CATS - I do this explicitly a lot, just to get the points: "This is relevant because it shows how political leaders..." etc. etc. Also, yes - this is pretty useless and uneeded! These notes, while I think they can be helpful, I didn't write these notes for you, I wrote them for myself... I just shared these because some might find it useful. What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? Reforms - show how political leaders can improve/democratize the nation "Gridlock"/"Deadlock", political leaders keeping things the same and preventing change Loss of control preventing changes - political leaders might be unable to create changes due to a lack of control Centralized planning - centralized planning shows how political leaders can plan and organize their government How did people contribute to political changes in their country? Protests/Resistance - pressure leaders/government to create political change Suppression - people are unable to contribute to political change due to suppression _What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan?
Industrialization - China and Taiwan's attempts at improving their industry and turning into manufacturing countries
Nationalization - a.k.a Collectivization, where governments try to control everything in a top-down structure and are extremely inefficient
"Exportization" - Industrialization but more about the conversion to export-based economies where nations outsourced their work too Reforms

archive/history-of-asia/history-practice.title: History Practice Essay
archive/history-of-asia/history-practice.description:
TWE did the people/government lead to social change?Step 1: Analysis, find angles
"Social change" I would immediately ask if it's political or economic or both. Assuming it's both, what I would then find what the TWE is - in this case, I'm assuming the spectrum is the people vs. the government
So my evidence is arguing the specific questions:
To what extent did the people vs. the government lead to political and economic change? Step 2: Planning
Now that I know the actual EQ:
I would then break it down into three themes
I want these themes to be political and economic and I need a counter, and preferably one which is much stronger
I would put some key concepts/umbrella terms with basic weighting
Economic policies? ()
Centralized planning? ()
Democraticization? (very strong for people)
econ growth? (strong for govt)
Suppression? (strong for govt)
Then, I chose the themes (democratization as counter, econ growth, centralized planning)
and chose E.VWarning
Remember that you need E.V from both China and Taiwan in each paragraph!
Wild Lily Movement
Tiananmen square - lack of social change
Cultural RevolutionKaohsiung Export Processing Zone
1st 5-year plan
S.O.EStep 3: thesis1st Draft:
While the social changes of democratization brought by the people were significantly important, social changes were overall brought mainly by the government: two major factors include centralized planning providing an overall direction for countries and economic policies that led to growth.2nd Draft:
I realized I do NOT want to write about centralized planning, as I'm stronger on the economic side. Tip
Since you always want to write about counter, place the counter first and place something like "While" conjunctions at the start for thesis structure or just use "however"
While the social changes of democratization brought by the people were of moderate importance, they were outweighed by the significantly important changes brought by economic policies and centralized planning of the government - overall, social changes were significantly influence by the government.Info
Remember to do all the thesis-y things
Write TWE weigh E.V etc. etc.
Step 3.5 CATS:
In a CATS, you weigh the theme in relation to other themes not to the overall thesis itself.The social changes of democratization were a major factor to why social changes were significantly influenced by the government and not completely influenced by the government.Social changes brought by economic policies are a highly significant factor to why the government significantly influenced social changes.Step 4: Write!The social changes of democratization were a major factor to why social changes were significantly influenced by the government and not completely influenced by the government.
One of the examples of successful democratization is the Wild Lily movement in 1990, a student led movement triggered by the funeral of the self-immolation of a journalist in Taiwan that demanded faster steps to democracy. The Wild Lily movement was successful and forced Lee Teng Hui to accept their demands, such as dissolving the national assembly and providing a timetable for clear steps towards a true democracy. The Wild Lily Movement shows how large, mass movements of people can place pressure on the government and demand social change towards democratization. Democratization is one of the most significant social changes inside a nation, a complete change of political structure. This is relevant because the Wild Lily movement shows how the people directly contribute towards democratization and thus social change - the people led this movement solely of their own volition, which shows how the government sometimes does not have full control of social changes.
However, suppression of people's movements also exists. One of the most extreme cases was the Tiananmen Square Incident in China in 1989, where over 300 civilians were shot down by the CCP military forces trying to clear Tiananmen square, filled with 2 million people. Afterwards, the CCP tightened censorship and prevented further steps towards democratization. Tiananmen square was the turning point for China, and the actions that the CCP prevented more people's movements in the future. As such, in China there has not been much social change since that period - there have no further mass demonstrations due to the prevention of people's movements. This is relevant because it shows us how when the people are unable to gather and unable to demonstrate, social changes are much more difficult to create. While the government can suppress and prevent changes, many actual social changes result from the people.
Furthermore, the Cultural Revolution is another example of how social changes must result from the people's actions. In the 1960s, Mao had lost power and needed to reclaim his status in the CCP. To do so, he created the four olds (old habits, customs, ideas, and structures) and utilized propaganda in order to create the Red Guards, his main troops during the Cultural Revolution. Mainly students, they idolized Mao and created chaos through China. The Cultural Revolution and the Red Guards show how even political leaders need people in order to change political structures. Mao needed to have actual people to rise back to the top of the CCP and put pressure on reformists to put him back in power. The Red Guards show how powerful people acting in large masses can be and how much change they can create - many intellectuals left China and China's reforms were mostly removed and reverted to Maoist/communist ideals. This is relevant because it shows how social change is physically executed by people. While Mao manipulated the people, the Cultural Revolution shows how governments and political leaders alone cannot create cultural change, as culture is controlled by the people's ideas. Only by manipulating the people can they truly create social change.Social changes brought by economic policies are a highly significant factor to why the government significantly influenced social changes. While the government alone cannot create cultural change, they can create economic policies that lead to economic change and improve living conditions, such as in the case of Taiwan's Kaohsiung Export Processing Zone. The government created an export processing zone that was solely for export, and had incentives for foreign investors. This caused the U.S and Japan to outsource their work to Taiwan, and significantly improved Taiwan's economy leading to the development of "Taiwan's Economic Miracle" where Taiwan was the fastest growing economy for 2 decades. The S.E.Z shows us how the government can contribute heavily to economic growth and improve living conditions for its population. The government was solely responsible for the creation of the economic zone and the incentives that allowed for so many factories and businesses to prosper, which shows us how economic growth in Taiwan was triggered by the government's actions. As such, many of the improvements and changes to living conditions were caused by the Taiwanese government. Furthermore, governments can also completely control the economy, such as with the 5-year plans first instituted in China in 1952. The 1st 5-year plan led to many quantifiable improvements - coal production went from 65 million tons to 130 million tons a year, steel and iron production tripled, and railways increased significantly. The second 5-yea plan had goals set too high and led to mass starvation in China. The 5-year plans show us how governments have immense control over their economic policies which have a massive effect on the population. While the 1st 5-year plan led to many improvements for the people of China, the Great Leap Forward was unsuccessful and killed millions. The 5-year plans show how governments have great control over the living conditions of their population via economic policies. Living conditions, an example of social changes, can be greatly influenced by the government for better or for worse.
Another example of the influence of governments on social changes and economic policies is Deng's conversion of China from a communist country to one of "socialism with Chinese Characteristics", or a market-based country. Deng's conversion of China to a more capitalist economy shows how economic policies by governments can alter the identity of a country - a key part of the identity of a country is its economic structure and ideology. Deng's conversion of China's economic structure is relevant because it shows how governments can control a countries' identity. Economic changes brought by governments can create massive social changes such as converting the entire economic structure of a nation.

archive/history-of-asia/household-respon.title: Household Responsibility System
archive/history-of-asia/household-respon.description:
Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-27
The Household Responsibility System was similar to the original Collectives, where farmers could sell their surplus - this was one of Deng's Economic Reforms and led to a 10% increase in agriculture yearly, being adapted by most farmers throughout China. Overall: What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (A-) The Household Responsibility system shows how political leaders can create policies that are not as planned and create economic reforms in their country
The autonomy that was given to the farmers also show how the CCP started to relax centralized control - similar to Special Economic Zones! How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (F) Not political changes, economic changes only What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (A) One of the critical reasons why there was economic success in China was the fact that Deng relinked productivity to rewards, causing many people to The household responsibility system increased agricultural productivity in China, a part of China's economic success

archive/history-of-asia/hundred-flowers..title: Hundred Flowers
archive/history-of-asia/hundred-flowers..description:
Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-25
The 1956 Hundred Flowers policy was a policy where Mao decided to relax censorship, thinking of the Zhou dynasty where "a hundred schools of thought" bloomed. However, Mao underestimated the amount of criticism and then led to the Anti-Rightist Movement where he hunted down those that opposed him. This led to a loss of intellectuals from China and the re-tightening of censorship.
Overall: (B) it has to be connected with the Anti-Rightist Movement to really be powerful What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (A+) This shows how political leaders control the flow of information Mao was able to immediately restrict or relax information flow The Hundred Flowers program shows how political leaders have the power to control information, and thus control their population
USE WITH Anti-Rightist Movement How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (B+/A-) This is actually really good as a counter, to show how political leaders wield so much power and control information that people can't contribute to political changes
If you want to use this, please also use Anti-Rightist Movement What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (C)
Potentially good, but the much better evidence for relaxation that could lead to economic reform is Deng's Economic Reforms

archive/history-of-asia/industrializatio.title: Industrialization
archive/history-of-asia/industrializatio.description:
Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-22
Industrialization occurred in China and Taiwan, where the development of heavy industry was the goal of China's 5-Year Plans, and Taiwan's Economic Miracle was partially due to industrialization. Industrialization is when nations attempt to heavily develop their industry, for example steel manufacturing, and in the case of China and Taiwan go from agricultural-based countries to export based ones (see Special Economic Zones).This is a general topic, so please use examples of industrialization and not just industrialization Overall: B- What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (A)
Industrialization is usually heavily led by the government, such as the 5-Year Plans, which show how political leaders play a big part of the economic direction of their country, like Deng's Economic Reforms This shows us how political leaders drive economic success and thus improve living conditions in their country How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (C+)
Industrialization is difficult to argue for this EQ, but you could use Living Room Factories/homemade iron smelters Great Leap Forward to show how the people can contribute to industrialization, and drive economic success This shows us how people can drive economic changes and improve living conditions in their country More convoluted and has weaker evidence than political leaders. What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (A) Heavy industrialization led to massive economic gains as China and Taiwan turned into export nations and other countries outsourced manufacturing to these countries. A key factor of economic success in China/Taiwan was how they became export nations after Industrialization.

archive/history-of-asia/kaohsiung-incide.title: Kaohsiung Incident
archive/history-of-asia/kaohsiung-incide.description:
Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-25
The Kaohsiung incident in 1979 was a pro-democracy demonstration in Taiwan, and had a significant crackdown by the police, even after Martial Law had ended. Overall: (B-) What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (A-) The government's reaction to the Kaohsiung incident shows us how political leaders can maintain control even without explicit military control Even after martial ended, the violent crackdown shows us how political leaders always have power and always have a say in the political changes that occur in a country. How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (A) The Kaohsiung Incident shows us how people used demonstrations and rallies in order to galvanize others and put pressure on the government to create political change. What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (F) No relation

archive/history-of-asia/living-room-fact.title: Living Room Factories
archive/history-of-asia/living-room-fact.description:
Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-25
Living Room Factories were a key part of Taiwan's economic miracle, where families produced goods by piecework and then sent them to a larger plant to assemble. They allowed families to directly gain extra money and contribute to Taiwan's Economic Miracle, giving a source of low labor costs. However, they also reduced education of people due to children going to work to earn money quickly. Overall: (B-) What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? No relation How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (B) While there are no political changes, the living room factories show us how people can contribute to economic changes which turned Taiwan into one of the "Asian Tigers", gaining a lot of political power What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (S)
Living room factories motivated the people and increased productivity, and also helped Taiwan reduce it's labor costs - a key factor why U.S and Japan outsourced their manufacturing to Taiwan for Taiwan's Economic Miracle
The reduced labor costs caused by the Living Room factories led to Taiwan's Economic Miracle and massive economic gains

archive/history-of-asia/martial-law.html.title: Martial Law
archive/history-of-asia/martial-law.html.description:
Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-25
The period of time in Taiwan where the KMT government imposed undemocratic restrictions on things like free speech and voting, triggered by 228. During this period of time the government abused its power, imprisoning or executing many people under the claim of combating communism. Taiwan was militaristic/authoritarian for most of this time period, but resistance triggered reforms in Taiwan. Overall: B What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (S) Taiwan's martial law period is essential to show us how political leaders have can nearly full control over their population - under martial law, the KMT police spied on everyone and entered houses often The power of the KMT shows us how political leaders in authoritarian regimes are indirectly responsible for every change, due to their immense control How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (F) No relation (examples of resistance are separate pieces of evidence which are related) What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (F) No relation

archive/history-of-asia/nationalization..title: Nationalization
archive/history-of-asia/nationalization..description:
Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-22
Nationalization or collectivization is when a nation seizes private property and turns it into public property - in China, Communes and Collectives were an example, where collectives forced farms to combine and produce grain for the government.
It can also generally apply to anytime the government controls a significant aspect of a country, for example State Owned Enterprises which were government-controlled companies. Overall: B+ What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (A) Collectivization allowed political leaders to create a top-down structure in their government and centralize their resources and control Collectivization shows how political leaders can centralize and create top-down structures, creating big changes in social and economic life It shows how the govt. can override individual rights in order to achieve their goals How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (C) Some people resisted collectivization and tried to remain independent or only in a commune But the main point is about how political leaders can seize assets and override individual rights What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (A+)
Nationalization and a top-down structure led to economic failure as State Owned Enterprises that were controlled by the government
These SOEs were extremely inefficient, and dragged down China until Deng's Economic Reforms created Special Economic Zones that let individuals and market dynamics control the economy, which was much more efficient

archive/history-of-asia/peaceful-power-t.title: Peaceful Power Transition
archive/history-of-asia/peaceful-power-t.description:
Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-25
Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-25
The ending of Martial Law by Chiang Ching Kuo ended most of the "White Terrors" of the White Terror period in 1987, yet the Wild Lily Movement shows how for some people, change did not come fast enough. Overall: B What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (S) The ending of martial law is a big change that shows how leaders can directly lead to democratization in their country and create reform How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (B)
Ending of Martial Law shows how the pressure placed on the government due to 228 and Kaohsiung Incident forced the government to create reforms However, not as strong due to U.S complaining that Martial Law was too strict contributed heavily to reforms What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (F) No relation The first presidential election in Taiwan was won by Lee Teng Hui in 1996 demonstrated that Taiwan had converted to a democracy. It was triggered by lee Teng Hui after multiple protests pushing Taiwan to a democracy. Lee Teng Hui may have won due to missile tests by China at the same time, threatening Taiwan militarily Overall: (C+) What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (A)
The presidential election shows how political leaders can democratize their country, similar to Ending of Martial Law, but it's slightly weaker as it wasn't as big of a change - Taiwan already had major democratic steps and Lee Teng Hui was just following through How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (B-) This shows how the people were able to place enormous pressure on the government and fully convert Taiwan into a democracy, that was unbiased and not rigged What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (F) No relation

archive/history-of-asia/red-guards.html.title: Red Guards
archive/history-of-asia/red-guards.html.description:
Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-23
The red guards were mainly students motivated by Mao Zedong during the Cultural Revolution, aiming to destroy the four olds: old customs, old culture, old habits, and old ideas. These students, often teenagers and young adults straight out of high school, were fervent believers in Mao's ideology and were eager to participate in what they saw as a revolutionary movement. They were the main "troops" of the Cultural Revolution, and as such, they carried out many of the policies and directives issued by Mao and his supporters. This included denouncing and persecuting individuals deemed to be counter-revolutionary, confiscating property, and destroying cultural artifacts. Their actions often led to chaos and violence, disrupting social order and causing immense suffering for countless people. They were eventually controlled and shut down by Mao after he regained power. Overall: A- What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (A+) The Red Guards show how Mao and political leaders can control their population By controlling propaganda and creating a cult of personality, political leaders can influence changes and influence people to cause great changes --> in this case, destroying and hurting many people How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (A) The Red Guards were able to shift the power dynamic of the CCP, restoring Mao to power and thus being able to shift the entire landscape of a country. This shows how people in large groups can influence through demonstrations and actions and reduce the power of certain groups (intellectuals lost power) and thus change the social and poltiical structure of countries. What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (C+)
The Cultural Revolution and destruction by the Red Guards caused a lot of damage You could infer that this damage led to economic stagnation and was a distraction to economic growth, but it's an inference, not a direct connection.

archive/history-of-asia/special-economic.title: Special Economic Zones
archive/history-of-asia/special-economic.description:
Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-22
Special Economic Zones helped develop China and Taiwan's economy. They were zones specifically for manufacturing and exports only, and in China, diverged from the communist ideals allowing people to benefit from their work and were a critical part of Deng's Economic Reforms, and had enormous growth averaging 30% per year (p. 133) Overall: B+ What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (A+) Special economic zones were completely designed by the government and driven by the government. This shows how political leaders can improve living conditions, and in the case of Deng, change the political direction of a country. It also shows how How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (F) The people did not pressure leaders for special economic zones, but they did use them in order to benefit and climb the societal ladder.
The people did not contribute to political change with special economic zones. (but see Living Room Factories) if you want some economic people based changes What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (S+)
Special economic zones turned China and Taiwan into export based nations that increased dramatically economically Taiwan's Economic Miracle

archive/history-of-asia/state-owned-ente.title: State Owned Enterprises
archive/history-of-asia/state-owned-ente.description:
Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-22
State owned enterprises were inefficient companies in China that resulted from Nationalization, where the government created top-down controlled companies to try and develop quickly. While they helped give everyone an "iron rice bowl", allowing everyone guaranteed jobs, they were inefficient and drained the government's resources and produced shoddy products. (p. 133) Overall: What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (B) Political leaders were able to create organizations that were unsuccessful However, the longevity and difficulty to change them much shows how political leaders create long-standing institutions that can last for a long time, limiting change. How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (F) No connection to people, mainly to the government What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (A) SOEs contributed heavily to economic failure/stagnation due to the large investment with little return in China
SOEs were inefficient and thus weakened China, slowing down China and draining resources that could have went to other sectors like productive Special Economic Zones

archive/history-of-asia/sunflower-moveme.title: Sunflower Movement
archive/history-of-asia/sunflower-moveme.description: Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-25A protest in Taiwan in 2014 against Ma Ying-jeou's Agreement to tie itself closer to China's economy. Fearing for Taiwan's sovereignty, the students occupied government buildings and protested the agreement, which was eventually shot down. Overall: (B-) What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (C+ stretch) Ma Ying-Jeou led the government's actions and policies, and indirectly created a stronger sense of identity for the Taiwanese people and united the Taiwanese people. How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (A+) This event shows us how people, even in a democratic society directly influence political outcomes such as the passing of legislations via protests and pressure on political figures, which shows how they can resist government policy. What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (F) Too recent to see effects + no relation (although they did try to get rid of an economic policy).

archive/history-of-asia/taiwan's-economi.title: Taiwan's Economic Miracle
archive/history-of-asia/taiwan's-economi.description:
Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-23
Taiwan's economic miracle is a term used to describe the massive improvements in Taiwan's economy. Heavy Industrialization was triggered by Special Economic Zones (Kaohsiung Export Processing Zone) and the Living Room Factories in Taiwan, creating tremendous economic growth as countries like the U.S realized they could get cheap labor in Taiwan. This allowed Taiwan's economy to grow significantly. Overall: What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (A-) Taiwan's economic miracle shows how political leaders can create great change for their country CCK's helped motivated foreign investors and drive a lot of economic growth How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (B-)
You could argue the Living Room Factories aspect of this, and show how the people who are motivated by economic benefits can contribute to a country's success.
But you should just use Living Room Factories as the main point. What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (S) Taiwan's economic miracle was triggered by having an export based economy This allowed it to make a lot of money and create tons of jobs Basically argue that Taiwan's economic miracle was triggered by export, and go from there.

archive/history-of-asia/tiananmen-square.title: Tiananmen Square
archive/history-of-asia/tiananmen-square.description:
Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-24
The Tiananmen Square Protests were a student-led pro-democracy movement started by the funeral of Hu Yaobang, that ended in a violent crackdown by Deng. This was the turning point similar to the Wild Lily Movement but instead of democratization (suggested by Zhao Ziyang), Deng cracked down and caused a massacre. At it's peak, the Tiananmen Square protest had over 2 million people blocking troops from entering the city (p. 136) Overall: (B+) What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (S) Deng and other leaders blocked political change, preventing democratic reform Tiananmen square shows how political leaders can prevent change Tiananmen square also shows how some political leaders (Zhao Ziyang) could lose power and not be able to have change How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (S) Tiananmen square is critical because it shows us how people can be suppressed While people can demand political change and contribute to reforms, they might also be suppressed and overruled What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (F) No relation

archive/history-of-asia/town-and-village.title: Town and Village Enterprises
archive/history-of-asia/town-and-village.description:
Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-27
Town and Village Enterprises (TVEs) were market-oriented public enterprises run by local governments (towns and villages) in rural China. Emerging in the 1980s as part of Deng's Economic Reforms, they played a significant role in China's economic growth (TODO lmao jard slacked off and slept) Overall: What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? How did people contribute to political changes in their country? What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan?
archive/history-of-asia/town-and-village.sourcePath: ARCHIVE/History of Asia/Town and Village Enterprises.md

archive/history-of-asia/white-terror.htm.title: White Terror
archive/history-of-asia/white-terror.htm.description:
Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-25
A period of time under martial law (1949-1987) after 228 where Taiwan suppressed and repressed the Taiwanese population - persecuting, executing, and imprisoning people such as in the case of Green Island. Overall: What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (S) Political leaders can prevent change and create "deadlocks" in order to maintain power The White Terror is the case of this carried to the extreme - no one could speak out or protest against the government It also shows how political leaders suppress identity as well! How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (B+)
Even in the midst of extreme political suprression, some people spoke out 228
Resistance during the White Terror was a key reason why Taiwan was able to democratize slowly, as the protests triggered U.S oversight and Taiwan slowly loosened up What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (F) No relation.

archive/history-of-asia/wild-lily-moveme.title: Wild Lily Movement
archive/history-of-asia/wild-lily-moveme.description: Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-25The Wild Lily Movement in Taiwan was a key movement in Taiwan's transition to democratize - Lee Teng Hui was forced to accept their 4 demands: the dissolution of the National Assembly, setting a democratic timeline, having a conference so the people could communicate their ideas, and abolition of the Temporary Provisions during Communist Rebellion. Overall: A What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (A-) Lee Teng Hui was forced to accept the protestor's 4 demands, which shows two things: Reforms: political leaders can accept reforms and democratize the country Losing Control: The Wild Lily Movement shows how political leaders can lose control over their population, being forced to accept changes - which shows how sometimes political leaders are powerless. How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (S) People, gathering in large groups can fight for reforms and pressure the government to change The Wild Lily movement forced the Taiwan government to democratize, which shows how people can put pressure on political leaders to force change What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (F) No relation

archive/hon-physics/light/concave.html.description:
#physics #light The focus is at half of the radius of the concave mirror Center of curvature is twice the focus distance, where the object looks the same size. The orientation is flipped until the object passes the focal point, but the image changes to a virtual image. Magnification is always smaller until you get closer to the focus, and because the center
Given the Mirror Equations we can show that the magnification is greater than 1 when there is a virtual image for a concave mirror only

archive/hon-physics/light/convex.html.title: Convex
archive/hon-physics/light/convex.html.description: #physics #light The focus is at half of the radius of the convex mirror Magnification is always less than one, so you always appear smaller The focus is always behind the mirror Always creates a virtual image Image is always upright (virtual image)

archive/hon-physics/light/diffraction.ht.title: Diffraction
archive/hon-physics/light/diffraction.ht.description:
Tags: #light Date: 2025-05-26 Diffraction bending of wave through obstacle You can use slits to measure wavelength
Double slit experiment shows constructive/destructive interference (also happens to prove wave nature of Wave-Particle Duality) What if we increase the amount of slits? Primary maximums remain at the same points Creation of secondary maximums Diffraction grating Notice how it depends on wavelength - lets us calculate wavelength and separate light! Many slits creating intermediate maximums, increasing intensity of interference pattern
When white light is shined into a diffraction grating, the different wavelengths have different interference patterns and maximums, creating a continuous Spectra

archive/hon-physics/light/lasers.html.title: Lasers
archive/hon-physics/light/lasers.html.description: Tags: #light Date: 2025-05-26 A.K.A Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation Emit pure light of one wavelength only Abuses the fact that atoms emit energy in specific increments Works by passing an electromagnetic wave through specific atoms, and as the wave reflects and becomes a standing wave, the light can be amplified in the optical cavity (until it leaves)

archive/hon-physics/light/law-of-reflect.title: Law of Reflection
archive/hon-physics/light/law-of-reflect.description: #physics #light The Angle of Incidence is equal to the Angle of Reflection of any incident ray.After reflection, the ray is called the reflected ray, and the source of the image seen (the Virtual Image) seems to come from within the mirror. Furthermore, because of this , the image distance and the viewing distance is the sameSee Lab 8-1 for the experiment to determine it

Convex lenses converge parallel light rays to a focal point. They form real, inverted images when the object is farther than the focal length. A lens that is thinner in the center than at the edges. Concave lenses diverge parallel light rays. They form virtual, upright images. Used in eyeglasses to correct nearsightedness (myopia

archive/hon-physics/light/observing-ligh.description: #physics #light Three ways to observe light Absorption Light is absorbed into object object is NOT that color Reflection Light reflects off object object is that color Transmission Light allowed to go through object object is that color Color cones in eyes allow us to detect light Long, medium, and short wavelengths Long (red) cone is sensitive to blue as well which lets us see purple Colorblindness Color receptors dysfunctional Monochromacy No color cones (1 in 30,000 people) Anomalous Trichromacy One color cone messed up 6.3% of men Why jard is colorblind 0.37% of women Eye has two lenses Cornea - converging lens Convex Lens - also converging lens! Adjusts the image distance Shortsighted is when this is too elongated, creating a poorly focused image Image forms behind retina Farsightedness Converging lens to form the image closer Nearsighted Diverging lens to form the image further away Myopia Presbyopia Astigmatism Different parts of lens/cornea forms different images Due to different

It works by limiting light rays through a small hole called an aperture. Pinhole cameras require longer exposure times for image development. 1st cameras every developed

archive/hon-physics/light/polarization.h.title: Polarization
archive/hon-physics/light/polarization.h.description:
#physics #light Polarization is when there is only a single plane of vibration
Principle behind Polaroid Filters unpolarized light scatters easily Polarized light can become unpolarized after scattering But scattering can also create polarized light! (see [[]])

archive/hon-physics/light/polaroid-filte.title: Polaroid Filters
archive/hon-physics/light/polaroid-filte.description:
#physics #light
Limit light to only one plane (Polarization) Invented by Edwin hall Broke into a physics lab after dropping out of Harvard Created using polymer acting like walls that prevent movement See figure Extremely useful for a variety of things Can fix glare after reflection, glare is typically horizontal So polaroid filter can filter all of the light and prevent it LCD screen Electrically controlled polaroid filters (Liquid Diode Crystals) that polarizes and can block or unblock specific pixels Via double polaroid filters, you can block ALL the light if you filter horizontal and vertical Light can only pass through one filter but not through both Light is polarized horizontallybut blocked by the verticalfiltersPasses through horizontal("underneath") Privacy screen 45 degree polaroid filter that splits light into components to get past the filters 3 layers of filters, middle one is 45 degrees that reorients the light Allows some light through, blocks all when the middle polaroid filter is removed The light ends up being half as intense normally First layer allows verticallight throughSecond layer allows 45 degreecomponent of light throughLast layer allows only horizontalcomponent through 3D glasses One vertical filter one horizontal filter Forces eyes to create the 3D image from two separate images Used to be color filters

archive/hon-physics/light/principal-focu.title: Principal Focus
archive/hon-physics/light/principal-focu.description: #physics #light In a Concave mirror, there is a principal focus where all of the rays converge outside of the mirrorIn a Convex mirror, the light reflects as if there is a focus within the mirrorThe principal focus is where all light rays must cross, which could mean that the rays intersect and enter the focus or the place where the rays seem to come from in a convex mirror, after the light reflects and the virtual image is always in the same place

archive/hon-physics/light/ray-diagram.ht.title: Ray Diagram
archive/hon-physics/light/ray-diagram.ht.description:
#physics #light Two rays emanating from a single point on the image Flat Draw one perpendicular and another that reflects off, then draw their intersection for virtual image.
Concave & Convex mirrors
- ==If the ray is parallel to the principal axis, it will reflect and go through the focus - ==If the ray is going through the focus, it will reflect and be parallel to the principal axis
- Concave is caved in - One ray parallel to the principal axis which will reflect through the focus - One ray through the object and principal focus which will reflect and create a ray parallel to the principal axis - In the case of the object being closer than the focus, draw from the focus to the object - 3 main cases - Object is behind focus - Object is between focus and center of curvature - Object is in front of focus
- Convex is facing outwards (i.e not caved in) - One ray parallel to the principal axis that reflects off and seems to intersect the focus

archive/hon-physics/light/rayleigh-scatt.title: Rayleigh Scattering
archive/hon-physics/light/rayleigh-scatt.description: #physics #light Rayleigh scattering Shorter the wavelength, the more light scattered Sky is blue during day because light scattered extremely quickly thus, blue light spreads out and makes entire sky blue when sun is overhead Red at dusk because blue scatters too much Sun's ray travel the furthest through the atmosphere, only unscattered light can go through

archive/hon-physics/light/refraction.htm.title: Refraction
archive/hon-physics/light/refraction.htm.description:
Tags: #light Date: 2025-05-22 The bending of light as it passes from one medium to another. Caused by the change in the speed of light in different media. The amount of bending depends on the angle of incidence and the refractive indices of the two medium
See Snell's Law (Law of Refraction) From fast -> slow medium, the light refracts towards the normal line
From slow-> fast medium, the light refracts away from the normal line leading to Total Internal Reflection

archive/hon-physics/light/snell's-law-(l.title: Snell's Law (Law of Refraction)
archive/hon-physics/light/snell's-law-(l.description:
Tags: #physics Date: 2025-05-19 Describes the relationship between the angles of incidence and refraction when light passes between two mediums
Basically, the law of Refraction , where: and are the refractive indices of the two media. and are the angles of incidence and refraction, respectively. The refractive index of air is approximately 1.000263.
Slow to fast Velocity --> bend away from normal Fast to slow medium -> bend towards normal Imagine drag of car on road at angle sides slow at different rates
Frequency remains constant during refraction Dispersion: index of refraction usually decreases when the decreases Violet bends more than red

archive/hon-physics/light/spectra.html.title: Spectra
archive/hon-physics/light/spectra.html.description: Tags: #light Date: 2025-05-26 Any set of wavelengths of light Types of Spectra Continuous Energy of ALL wavelengths Thermal/Blackbody Creates light at all wavelengths Discrete Energy at a particular wavelength Each element has a couple of energies that they absorb, creating an absorption spectrum Continuous gets absorbed Stars, e.g some atoms Doppler effect can shift absorption lines Emission spectra Exciting elements at specific intervals Only some wavelengths are emitted Helium first discovered via emission from sun Create the same spectrum as absorption spectrum because elements absorb and excite in specific energy potentials Potential energy drop gives frequencies, which are the same across absorption and emission spectra

archive/hon-physics/light/spectroscopy.h.title: Spectroscopy
archive/hon-physics/light/spectroscopy.h.description: Tags: #light Date: 2025-05-26 Spectroscopy Telling things from the composition of light Spectrometer Tool that split light according to wavelength example: Mars exploration missions Usage of spectrometers to tell details of rocks and samples

archive/hon-physics/light/virtual-image..description:
#physics #light This happens when the reflected rays diverge thus making it impossible to project onto a screen A real image is able to be projected as light rays still intersect in front of the mirror The image of the object inside the mirror The reflected rays act like they are receiving light rays from the virtual image itself By viewing the virtual image, everything is identical compared to looking at the object from the same distance
Because Law of Reflection

archive/hon-physics/light/wave-particle-.title: Wave-Particle Duality
archive/hon-physics/light/wave-particle-.description: Tags: #physics #QM Date: 2025-05-26 Dual property of light - wave and particle 1000A.D first proposed that light was tiny particles Huygens proposed that light was a wave Supported by Thomas Young with interference experiment Further supported by Maxwell's equations that said light was a wave and EM waves traveled at the speed of light Newton proposed that light was a particle Explained reflection and refraction 1900 supported by Planck Blackbody radiation curve predicted by particles Heinrich Hertz Photoelectric effect Frequency Threshold, confused everyone Solved by Einstein Proposed photon particles, explained light as wave and particle

archive/hon-physics/magnetism/domains.ht.title: Domains
archive/hon-physics/magnetism/domains.ht.description: #physics #magnetism Local regions in a material that are magnetically unaligned OVERALL But the individual regions' electrons are aligned! Formed with electrons pointing in the same direction to produce a net force Too random normally so the net force balances out to 0 These regions align when a magnetic field is applied to magnetize a material

archive/hon-physics/magnetism/electromag.title: Electromagnets
archive/hon-physics/magnetism/electromag.description:
#physics #magnetism #electricity
Via Induction an electric current is able to induce a magnetic field 3 ways to increase strength Increase number of coils Coils of wire are called solenoids Increase current Add a ferromagnetic core (to strengthen field)
Inside an actual magnet the domains also end up being like electromagnets!

archive/hon-physics/magnetism/generators.title: Generators
archive/hon-physics/magnetism/generators.description:
#physics #magnetism #electricity
Convert kinetic energy to electrical energy by moving a Magnet
Via Induction we know that an electric field will be generated Also works the other way around You can feed electric field to move the magnets! Becomes a motor if converting electrical energy to kinetic energy All motors are generators and vice versa!

archive/hon-physics/magnetism/induction..title: Induction
archive/hon-physics/magnetism/induction..description:
#physics #magnetism #electricity Changing magnetic fields can induce changing electric fields And changing electric fields can induce changing magnetic fields
Principle behind Electromagnets Anytime charges move you can create a magnetic field Electromagnets = moving current = moving charges = magnetic field!
Principle behind Generators Keep changing the magnetic field (by moving a magnet) and you can produce an electric field!

archive/hon-physics/magnetism/magnet.htm.title: Magnet
archive/hon-physics/magnetism/magnet.htm.description:
#physics #magnetism Has two poles, north and south North is negative, south is positive Field lines always go from north to south ALWAYS HAS TWO POLES, EVEN IF THE MAGNET IS SPLIT Magnetic field is strongest at the poles Unlike poles attract, north + south attract, like poles repel (north/north or south/south) Magnetic field Formed by EM waves moving back and forth (but that's AP Physics C) Field force like gravity Permanent magnet A magnet that is always "on" If split, forms two poles Temporary magnet
Magnetized via bringing a magnetic field close to it to polarize the Domains "Hard" temporary magnets are difficult to magnetize and difficult to unmagnetize Strongest ones are Neodymium magnets Conversely "soft" are easy to magnetize and easy to unmagnetize
Electromagnets Magnets formed via induction

archive/hon-physics/magnetism/right-hand.title: Right Hand Rule
archive/hon-physics/magnetism/right-hand.description: #physics #magnetism #electricity TWO RIGHT HAND RULES Force on moving charges Thumb: velocity Fingers: Magnetic field Palm: force The force is inverted for negative charges!! Parallel charges have no force (not moving across field lines) X marks are into the paper, means away Imagine it like an arrow Magnetic field around wire Point thumb in direction of velocity Direction fingers curl is direction of the magnetic field

archive/hon-physics/waves/doppler-effect.title: Doppler Effect
archive/hon-physics/waves/doppler-effect.description: Tags: #physics #waves Date: 2025-05-13 Change in pitch/apparent frequency for an observer when the source is moving towards or away - Towards increases the frequency ("compresses" the wave) - Moving away decreases the frequency Note that it's apparent frequency, not actual frequency

archive/hon-physics/waves/frequency.html.title: Frequency
archive/hon-physics/waves/frequency.html.description:
Tags: #physics Date: 2025-05-13 The frequency of a wave is how many periods it goes through per second
Related to the Wavelength of a wave via the wave speed equation The velocity is CONSTANT in a medium, only the frequency and wavelength change

archive/hon-physics/waves/harmonics.html.title: Harmonics
archive/hon-physics/waves/harmonics.html.description:
Tags: #physics #waves Date: 2025-05-13
A harmonic is a Frequency when a Standing Wave is generated Warning Make sure to use the correct formula for fixed vs. open boundaries! Fixed/Free end: for positive odd integers Fixed end: for all positive integers For every nodes the standing wave has (the th harmonic), the frequency of the harmonic is such that , where is the distance to the boundary - Extending this for the th harmonic WITH A FIXED BOUNDARY is - Therefore the frequency must be The 1st harmonic is called the Resonant Frequency

archive/hon-physics/waves/interference.h.title: Interference
archive/hon-physics/waves/interference.h.description:
Tags: #physics #waves Date: 2025-05-13 Occurs when two waves meet crest to crest or crest to trough "Phase" is direction of the phase "In phase" is when the two waves vibrate in the same direction "Out of phase" is when two waves vibrate in opposite directions Two types Constructive Increases wave amplitude AMPLITUDE, NOTHING ELSE Occurs when waves are in phase Destructive Decreases wave amplitude Occurs when waves are out of phase Same concept is used in noise cancelling headphones to "destroy" oustide waves Special type of interference When waves reflect off a boundary they can sometimes reflect back onto themselves and constructively interfere Causes amplitude to continue increasing
Occurs only on Harmonics, certain frequencies

archive/hon-physics/waves/resonance.html.title: Resonance
archive/hon-physics/waves/resonance.html.description:
Tags: #physics #waves Date: 2025-05-13
When wind or other small forces generate a Standing Wave
If the force matches a Harmonic of a structure, a standing wave can be generated Example: Tacoma Bridge Incident where the wind matched the Led to engineers making bridges that had sections with different resonant frequencies

archive/hon-physics/waves/velocity.html.title: Velocity
archive/hon-physics/waves/velocity.html.description:
Tags: #physics #waves Date: 2025-05-13 "Velocity" is how fast the wave travels through the medium
Relates Wavelength and Frequency The velocity is CONSTANT in a medium, only the frequency and wavelength change The wave velocity only depends on medium
Well, in some rare cases like in Refraction this is not the case, the velocity actually changes on wavelength But generally, velocity is constant Increase speed via increasing tension of the medium (need to change medium itself)

archive/hon-physics/waves/wave-types.htm.title: Wave Types
archive/hon-physics/waves/wave-types.htm.description: Tags: #physics #waves Date: 2025-05-13 Pulse waves Single, one-time waves Periodic waves Consistently generated waves Longitudinal waves Waves that have their movement parallel to the direction "particles" are vibrating "Particles" is just the medium Examples: Sound, Slinky Transverse Waves Biggest example is light! Waves that have their movement perpendicular to the direction "particles" are vibrating

archive/honors-alg-2/exponents-&-logs/in.description:
#math Inverse functions are functions which reverse the process of a given function, basically changing x and y --> this basically allows you to get your inputs back from your outputs. Inverse functions only exists for one to one functions! You must domain restrict a function if it's not one to one! Represented as Properties
The composition of the inverse and the normal function will always return the input --> if you get your inputs back from your outputs, it'll be the input again. Mathematically Domain and range flip when you invert Graphically, acts like a reflection over the line

archive/honors-alg-2/exponents-&-logs/si.description:
#logs #math You may be asked to condense or expand logarithms, and they have different rules to follow. Log Condensing Rules The coefficient must be 1 Rational exponents should be written in radical form Leave the input in radical form No need to rationalize! Expanding Logs No power, product, or quotient should remain in the input Numerical logs should be in simplest terms.
Evaluate logs as much as possible () Use the Log Properties to simplify logs. Note that a lot of people mess these up, make sure to take extra care when using these!An interesting problem on the last quiz involved an expression that simplified to Now, you can actually simplify this further via change of base!

#math #exponents PLEASE PLEASE REMEMBER TO CHECK YOUR ANSWERS! Methods
Exponential One to One The most general method, anytime you have two exponentials to the same base you can set and solve from there. Noncheckable
U-sub Useful when you get a quadratic looking exponentials, usually of the form Checkable
Logarithmic methods - Useful when you can't solve cleanly into bases. You can use any log on an equation like to isolate x - and you can solve from there. - Checkable-ish Always check if you can use One to One, then U-sub, then logs to make it easier. The goofy example here is where you can distribute the logs to isolate, which is something you definitely want to keep in mind e.g

#logs #mathPLEASE PLEASE REMEMBER TO CHECK YOUR ANSWERS!
Logs One-to-One Useful anytime you only have log expressions
Changing to Exponential - Useful for everything else!
- Technically you can get here by doing Logs One-to-One by subtracting a 1-1 on both sides and simplifying... You only have two strategies: rewrite everything as two logs on both sides, or rewrite everything as the same base. Everything else won't solve cleanly. Always see if you can easily Logs One-to-One first, as it's a little bit cleaner

archive/honors-alg-2/exponents-&-logs/te.title: Terminology
archive/honors-alg-2/exponents-&-logs/te.description:
#math #logs #exponentsThe power is the entire expression (), and the exponent is only the value that determines how many times something is multiplied. () The base is the value that is being raised by an exponent (). e, Euler's number is an irrational number that is the limit of a function ln is the log with base e , called the natural log because of how often it appears in nature Usually, logs without bases are and called the common log But in computer science logs without bases are so don't take it for granted! Solve Leave answer as expression Solve for a variable Evaluate results in an actual value Simplify Make cleaner or more compact Pateledefinition: less operations
Logs: Condensing/Expanding
Exponential: Simplifying Exponentials In the expression , is the growth factor, it determines how fast the exponential function grows Used to determine if a function is growth or decay In exponential functions, it's in which also turns out to be the y-intercept (because )

archive/honors-alg-2/exponents-&-logs/te.title: Test Strategy
archive/honors-alg-2/exponents-&-logs/te.description:
Some of these are guesses, which are italicized Calculator At least one using general formulas Probably one that asks you to get the input back One intersection MCQs Conceptual understanding FRQs Testing problem solving skills Writing???? Graphing Exponents Expand to increase options then simplify U-sub to help manage your variables U-sub as soon as you see quadratic like stuff Or just condense, as long as you try to reduce the problem to make it easier reach a position where you can log, one-one, U-sub
- log -> get two clusters, one with all the powers, one with all the values and log the entire thing to isolate the exponents
- one-one -> get powers of the same base on both sides and then solve - You can't do one-one if there are any elements that are not powers, always change everything to same base if you want to use this
- U-sub -> only use when you see multiple repeated powers, especially quadratic-like equations - Useful for the simplifying step as well to make math cleaner For U-Sub, remember your equation for u is not the same as the initial variable you were solving for!!! And always check!!! Logs You only have two strategies: rewrite everything as two logs on both sides, or rewrite everything as the same base.
Logs One-to-One
Rewriting as Exponential PLEASE PLEASE CHECK LOGS, YOU ALSO NEED TO CHECK FOR U-SUB Why hard? You gonna forget that you can't do your log rules on negative logs No solution/Undefined What is the inverse function of ? Why hard? Forgetting to range restrict or Find all integer solutions for x,m Why hard? Too many ways to try to approach this at the start, approach it by trying to simplify as much as possible Recommendation: Expand first, then condense! Find the loudness of a noise that has 15 kW per square kilometer Why hard? You forget to convert the units to what the inputs were supposed to be... Transformations Always factor out the coefficients of Focus on the key point

Domain For even-numbered indicies, the radicand must be non-negative. Key Points: Starting Point: The point where the radicand is zero, i.e., . End Behavior: Depends on the index and the sign of . Steps: Identify the domain of the function (where the radicand is non-negative for even indices). Find the starting point by setting and solving for . Determine the end behavior based on the sign of and the index . Plot additional points to sketch the graph. Examples: : Basic square root function, starts at (0,0), increases to the right. : Basic cube root function, passes through (0,0), increases for all .

archive/honors-alg-2/radicals/simplifyin.title: Simplifying Radicals
archive/honors-alg-2/radicals/simplifyin.description:
Tags: #math #radicals Date: 2025-05-13
Radicand should be fully simplified via Radical Properties Pull out every perfect th power, where is the index. The denominator of all terms should NOT have a radical Rationalize by multiplying the numerator and denominator by a suitable radical expression. Can't be simplified when... The radicand is negative and the index is even (in the realm of real numbers). The radicand has no perfect th power factors (other than 1). **You need to add when the index and radicand are even, and it becomes an odd indexed exponent Steps: Factor the radicand into prime factors. Identify pairs (or triplets, etc., depending on the index) of identical factors. Take each group of factors outside the radical, reducing the exponent by a factor of . Multiply the terms outside and inside the radical. Rational exponent form
Represent everything as a rational exponent (see Radical Properties) Radical form Make sure to rationalize!

archive/honors-alg-2/rationals/graphing-.title: Graphing Rational Functions
archive/honors-alg-2/rationals/graphing-.description: Tags: #math #rationals Date: 2025-05-13 Parent function: 1/x Asymptotes VA: what makes the bottom cancel out to zero  Ex. the VA is 1 HA: Three types  If the largest exponent in the numerator is greater than the largest exponent in the denominator then there is no horizontal asymptote! , the is greater than the x, no H.A Slant asymptote Special case where the power in the numerator is exactly 1 greater than the power in the denominator If the denominator's power is greater than the numerator's then the H.A is at 0 If the powers are the same then look at the coefficients Ex. , the HA is Holes: if the denominator and numerator can cancel out a term then whatever makes that term zero becomes a hole Basically, a way of keeping the domain restriction as in the original function that value cannot equal 0 Intercepts X - int: what makes the numerator zero  Basically after factoring, solve for the roots Maybe there will be a situation where the numerator is quadratic - still need to solve using quadratic formula! Y-int: plug in zero for x (ez)

archive/honors-alg-2/sequences-and-serie.title: Summation Notation
archive/honors-alg-2/sequences-and-serie.description:
#math #sequence If no notation given anything is game
First start by finding the sequence (Recognize) Summation/Sigma notation - - Expanded by plugging in the sequences itself for every term - Evaluate the sum of the entire sequence Example Leave upper limit without ... - Need to get summation from sequence - Get sequence first and then find upper/lower limits - Not this sigma , which is lowercase - Stands for standard deviation - Warning When counting the number of terms for any sequence/summation notation, remember that you can't just subtract start and end! You must include the first term as well (e.g term number 1)

archive/honors-alg-2/sequences-and-serie.title: Terminology
archive/honors-alg-2/sequences-and-serie.description:
#math #sequences #series Sequence Formally, a number sequence is a ordered list of numbers defined by a rule. The numbers of the sequence are called the terms Basically a list of terms with a pattern The domain must be the set of positive natural numbers. NOTE THAT 0 IS NOT INCLUDED N MUST START AT N=1 Finite Fixed amount Show end either with or just "Finite" could end on the general term, which is still infinite Infinite Use ellipses that continue to nothing No end, sequence evaluates for all natural numbers Bracket Notation is the whole sequence when there is bracket notation Make sure to have nth term at the end General Term Without brackets is the term for any term
Infinite Sums Series that converge to a point SERIES VS. SEQUENCE Sequences describe a pattern Series are just the sums of a number of terms in a sequence
