Test writing ideology Test should be worth 20% of your grade 32 MCQs targeting specific concepts and 4 FRQs, one for each unit just testing solving ability MCQs are SPECIFIC and hit one concept as the MAIN PIECE What makes the test difficult? Exp&Logs --> CONTENT. Inv Functions, a lot of properties, function comp, a lot of stuff that needs to be tested for means you get PUNISHED if you don't have enough breadth Writing hard test strat --> Test for breadth and make sure everything is tested, use MCQs to test for knowledge, evaluation questions that test log properties Rationals --> asymptotes and graphing, the rational graph has a lot of key details Writing hard test strat --> graphing problems and conceptual ones that target each key feature Radicals --> simplification, solving with domain restriction and absolute values Writing hard test strat --> a lot of FRQs around simplification Series and Sequences --> n/n+1, applying formulas Uniform motion when? How do you simplify rational, radical, exponential, and log equations? You should know the simplified form of each! Rationals Do you know how to find the LCD of rational functions?
Do you know how to solve Complex Rational Equations? Do you know how to find holes, asymptotes, domain/range, and other key features on a rational graph? Do you know how to calculate asymptotes? Radicals
Do you know how to solve double radical equations?
Do you know your Terminology? (index, radicand, etc.)
Do you know the Radical Properties? Exponentials
Do you know the Exponential Properties?
Do you know how to solve exponential equations using Exponential One to One, U-sub, and Logarithmic methods?
Do you know the key features of exponential graphs? Do you know the domain restrictions of exponential graphs? Logs
Do you know the Log Properties?
Do you know how to solve log equations using Logs One-to-One and Rewriting as Exponential?
Do you know the domain restrictions of the log function itself (see the note in Log Properties)?
Do you know the key features of log graphs? Sequences and Series
Do you know the terminology?
Can you Recognize, Describe, and Continue sequences?
Do you know the formulas for Arithmetic Series and Geometric Series?
Do you understand Infinite Sums and when a geometric series converges? General Functions
Do you know how to find the inverse of a function?
Do you know how to perform function composition? Throwing out some ideas here... Absolute hardest problems Double complex rational equation (E.g ) problems with domain-restricted solutions Log problems with exponents and change of base black magic to simplify Double radical problems with absolute value Series word problemWarning These are AI generated slop, may not have an actual answer yet! WIP. Test writing ideology Test should be worth 20% of your grade, around 100 points (3x quiz content) 1/3 of the test should be MCQs to test knowledge 2/3 of the test should be applying each and every formula we know Start by writing the formula questions, then go back and identify knowledge gaps and fill those in

to-code-a-robot/getting-started/getting-.title: Getting Started
to-code-a-robot/getting-started/getting-.description:
Tags: #to-code-a-robot #frc #coding Date: 2025-05-22Welcome to FRC! This section is a basic start to coding in FRC, and getting vital tools set up, like: Phoenix Tuner X: Diagnosis and Tuning tool for motors WPIlib: core library of all code WPIlib editor: core IDE REVlib: debugging and flashing Neo motors Git and Github: advanced version history. By the end of this section, you should be able to install every tool, setup the basic environment, and create your first project from a template!
Installing the Tools
Navigating the IDE

to-code-a-robot/getting-started/installi.title: Installing the Tools
to-code-a-robot/getting-started/installi.description:
Tags: #frc #coding #to-code-a-robot Date: 2025-06-05The most important tool to download is WPIlib's IDE (Integrated Development Environment) so you can actually write code on a robot.
WPIlib download After downloading the ISO file, right click it to mount the disk image. Then, run the WPIlib Installer. You may need to run as administrator or unblock it via "Properties" if Windows Defender "protects" your computer. Then, follow the instructions in the installer, but make sure to install VS code along with the rest of the tools. The installer will extract and help download the rest of the files. After following these steps, you should be able to find and run WPIlib VS Code 2025, which is the IDE you'll be using. While you can use other IDEs like Neovim, it's highly recommended to use the bundled VS code for ease of use and to avoid issues later on.
PathPlanner is a tool used to draw and plan out autonomous paths and implement them in code easily, it's vital for anything related to autonomous - you can download it off the Microsoft Store here.
Phoenix Tuner X is a tuning software to help tune and debug motors. You can download this from the Microsoft Store. Latest firmware for specific motors can be found on their GitHub page.
The REVlib Hardware Manager is used to debug and flash NEO Brushless motors - you can download it here.
Follow this tutorial or just click the Git icon in the sidebar and download from there.
You should make an account on GitHub as well.

to-code-a-robot/working-in-a-team/git-an.title: Git and Github Intro
to-code-a-robot/working-in-a-team/git-an.description:
Tags: #frc #coding #to-code-a-robot Date: 2025-06-12
Here's a quick 100 second intro to getting started with Git. Git is simply put, advanced version control. You make some edits, make a snapshot (a commit) of your code, so when you realize you made a massive mistake, you can revert and go back to that version. Another benefit of Git is the ability to make branches - you can branch off of stable working code, add and test a new feature, then merge it back into the stable branch. This is incredibly useful when working on a big project with multiple people: you can independently work on separate features. However, Git by itself is only for local use, to share and work online, you need to use GitHub to put your git workspace online. Tldr Git: Local branch & version control Github: Puts git work online for collaboration and backup (plus some additional features for collaboration)
Git and Github work with repositories, or codebases: the repo we will be using is this one: https://github.com/TASRobotics/RaidOne-2026-Offseason (ask Jared for access if you don't have it already).

to-code-a-robot/getting-started/navigati.title: Navigating the IDE
to-code-a-robot/getting-started/navigati.description:
Tags: #frc #coding #to-code-a-robot Date: 2025-06-12Tip Customize!!! Obviously, go ahead and customize your IDE setup - WPIlib VScode is VScode but with additional features, so you can do all the VScode things like download plugins and change your editor to light mode (if you woke up and chose violence). You'll be looking at this screen for a long, long time so do whatever you need to be happy with it (no judgement (except if you use light mode, everyone except for Jard will judge you)) Now that you've finished downloading WPIlib, you should learn how to create projects and use the command palette. You can access all commands using the shortcut Ctrl + Shift + P, but if you only want to see WPIlib based commands you can click the WPIlib logo This brings up a list of commands - the most important ones are build robot code and deploy robot code. Building the code checks it for errors, and deploying the code deploys it to the robot.
In the sidebar, there's also a WPIlib logo, and when you click it it shows the vendor dependencies. Vendor dependencies (vendordeps) are used to add additional function on top of default WPIlib function, such as CTRE Phoenix's libraries, which add motion magic (motion profiles). Go into the command palette and create a new project. When you get to the project creation screen, select the template option, then java, then "Command Robot Skeleton (Advanced)". This gives you a virtually blank slate to start from. Follow the rest of the directions (team number for R1 is 8503) to make the project!
Now, you're ready to move into Git and Github and start doing actual hands-on work.

to-code-a-robot/working-in-a-team/git-an.description:
Tags: #frc #coding #to-code-a-robot Date: 2025-05-22This section will be a start into learning Git/Github, which is simply advanced version control and sharing, along with a couple of advanced features. Being good at Git is a simple but vital skill in order to be able to do work - it shouldn't take too long to learn, but not learning the basics will waste your entire season. Also, the hands-on learning starts here! Please follow along and do the tasks to actually learn them.By the end of this lesson, you should be able to connect your repository to git and github, use vital git commands, clone from projects on the internet, create branches, and merge branches with and without pull requests.
Git and Github Intro
Git Commands
Branches
Pull Requests
GitHub features

to-code-a-robot/working-in-a-team/branch.title: Branches
to-code-a-robot/working-in-a-team/branch.description:
Tags: #frc #coding #to-code-a-robot Date: 2025-06-12Now, all you've been doing is working on the main branch, which is bad coding practice! Main is only for working, tested code. That's why you should branch off of main to test specific features. It also helps to keep others' broken code (and also your broken code) from messing up other people's code.
So, now that you now why we branch, make a branch yourself with your name using the git branch command (or again, you can use the GUI/command palette). Then inside your new branch, create a new blank template project. (see Creating your first project). This is now your branch, and it's where you'll be doing all your work. Now that you have your own branch, you might be wondering how we actually merge back into main. Merging is something you'll have to do a lot of, and you can do this via the git merge command. By merging, you'll create a new commit, and that commit will have two branches' code together.
However, you might have merge conflicts, which you MUST always resolve. Merge conflicts are pretty simple - you go through each file that has a conflict and select the code segment you want to keep. It's too hard to explain it in writing so here's a video tutorial: Video tutorial Usually, you should use the three-way editor which is a lot faster and simpler to use. It's a little hard to test for merge conflicts in a general sense, so I'll go through and make some manually when you start working on more complicated code.

to-code-a-robot/working-in-a-team/git-co.title: Git Commands
to-code-a-robot/working-in-a-team/git-co.description:
Tags: #frc #coding #to-code-a-robot Date: 2025-06-12Sometimes, you might find it easier to use the terminal rather than any GUI (graphical interface) to do Git work - some commands can only be done in the terminal! Open up a terminal within VScode via Ctrl + ` (backtick) or via the command palette. You may find it useful to change your terminal to Git Bash instead of Powershell for some commands. First things first: configure git via the Git Config command inside the terminal
(See here) Make sure to set it to the same username and email you use for GitHub! By configuring git, you tell git/github who you are, and what email address/user name to sign commits with. The first step to starting work is to clone (copy) the repository you want to work with.
You could probably create the repo first and push it online for local projects, but since the training repository already exists, use git clone on the training repo. Google/ChatGPT the answer yourself! Get used to doing a lot of googling and reading docs - you'll have to do this a lot during the season since there'll be a bunch you don't know.
Need help? https://docs.github.com/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-repositories/cloning-a-repository?platform=windows&tool=webui Git clone with clone everything - branches, history, etc. so don't worry about having to clone individual branches.After configuration and cloning, you can use the GUI if you like it better (some things, like resolving merge conflicts are disgusting in terminal). Let's start doing actual work: make a couple edits in the default README.md file and notice how the changes are untracked.
You have two options if you want to commit these changes (save/take a snapshot): you can stage specific files, or you can commit them all at once. Independently staging them has the benefit of being able to make small changes. However, in this case you can just commit - write a commit message in imperative tense (e.g add some text to README) and hit the fat commit button. Important Having good commit messages is extremely important when people want to see what you changed. The commit message should be in imperative tense: "If this commit is applied, it will ..." Also, make small commits so you can revert to more specific changes. While it seems really nitpicky to use imperative tense, when you're going through 600 commits you really want to be able to identify what specific changes you made instead of only being able to see "change some smol speed sturff". Some programmers have really bad habits and debugging their code sucks because of it. Now, you after you've made a commit, your job isn't done yet! You now have to push it online so others can see it. You can either click the sync button, or within terminal run git push to push your changes online. Something else to note is that Git doesn't automatically pull changes either - if someone made some changes, you'll have to sync or use git pull first.You can also push your changes online during the commit via the drop down menu.

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the closer connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make the graph appear more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.
